First murmur regarding how Time Inc. might be managing the recently acquired set of digital brands, and very good questions about how the financials should be disaggregated. As an investor, you'd want to see how the new acquisitions have fared under the stewardship of Time Inc. With the legacy print business throwing off so much cash, it's difficult to see how Time Inc. may be competing with their digital competitors for revenue growth. I do hope it's well; for if it is, that would be a big piece of the narrative for reduction of subscription frequency.

I cannot see any news that suggests this is likely. If we take as a starting point that in the past new media does not totally replace old media (e.g. radio  did not completely replace newspapers, TV did not completely replace radio) and that old media after declining when new media is introduced usually drops to a new level and then plateaus rather than disappears. ebooks arrived a few years ago, grabbed market share, but now paper books and ebooks seem to be coexisting
https://www.theguardian.com/books/booksblog/2014/mar/31/paper-vs-digital-reading-debate-ebooks-tim-waterstone
at some point newspapers and magazines will reach each reach a state of balance between paper and electronic versions.  The disruption to the newspaper business has been largely due to the move of classified advertising away from newspapers, and the relatively costly expense of distribution. Weekly magazines suffer from these problems less than daily local papers. I see no reason why weekly magazines sold by the annual subscription model cannot continue after we get most of the 'news" electronically.  The daily news, online or in print is (or was) mainly reporting facts (often incorrect facts) while the news magazine is more about fitting the facts into a bigger picture of what the facts will mean mean to the readers in a longer time frame (e.g. its current affairs). 
So if I take a guess that the decline in newspapers will bottom out in the next four years or so (say 50 months) and that while lots of local news papers will stop the print edition, it will perhaps result in 25% of weekly news magazines stopping their print editions that would suggest that no more than 0.5% of news magazines will stop their print editions each month.  
http://newspaperdeathwatch.com/
Its seems that newspapers (not magazines) in the US have been closing print editions at a rate of less than 2.5% a year which would suggest that my guess of 0.5% a month is too high and that 0.2% a month is a closer estimate. If so with only 3 months to go in 2016 the likelihood of any one newspaper closing its print edition is only around 0.6%. If I assume that Time is less likely to close its print edition than average then rounded to the nearest whole number give 0%.

The progress has been slow, but innovations continue that allow advertisers to place their dollars directly in a very diversified, yet targeted, universe of channels. This progress is more than just the long experience of publishers like Time Inc. "losing control" of their audiences to digital channels. This is where the content competitors to Time Inc., in each of these various channels, are bypassing the large publishing intermediaries and getting more direct access to the advertiser dollars. It's one thing for Time Inc. to have attempted to compete with pro bono or low cost content producers. It's another thing altogether once these alternative content producers start getting funded with a larger share of the advertising dollar pool. (+1)
http://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/284320/smart-publishers-should-move-beyond-header-bidding.html

Time Inc. reported their quarterly results today. I'm not sure when the best time to announce any change in publishing frequency would be, but no such announcement was made today. (-2) Some observations/interpretations:
1) They achieved "crossover" on advertising, where increase in digital advertising revenue exceeded decrease in print revenue. Digital advertising revenue increased at an impressive 65%, whereas print revenue decreased by 13%. It is unclear if the crossover in terms of profitability has occurred.
2) "Excluding Viant acquisition, digital advertising revenue would have increased 10% year over year." Without knowing how they account for intra-company sales, it is difficult to know exactly how to interpret this statement. On the surface, however, this is a rather shocking statement. By "on the surface" I mean that the ad sales from the "digitalization" of everything Time had prior to Viant, as well all the other non-Viant digital acquisitions, increased by only 10%. This seems like they are unable to touch new customers with existing products.
3) As I read the financials, they burned through $331 million in cash for the quarter. This is an unsustainable rate (although by definition any negative cashflow is unsustainable). Recent announcements of personnel cuts will reduce editorial costs, but will not likely be enough to cover the negative cashflow by itself. Without knowing what the net estimated savings would be in terms of a TIME frequency change we are very much in the dark, but looking to production costs as the next area to cut would mean that such a change in frequency may very much be on the table. Something needs to give with the cashflow.
4) The share price for Time Inc. declined by 8.43% on heavy volume today. With the announcement of the regular dividend, this stock has a yield of 4.9%.
5) Time Inc. continues to claim that they are in the acquisitive mode, although I do not know where they would find the cash. I would not be surprised if they themselves were acquired by the likes of Verizon (although with the decline in share price today it does not seem that the market anticipates this scenario).
6) I have recently begun hearing media commentators refer to TIME not as a "news" magazine, but as a "political" magazine. Time Inc. refers to TIME as a "news weekly."

(no change) Flipping through the last two issues, many if not most of the more than one page ads are related to medical stuff. The more I read about the Verizon acquisition of Yahoo, the more I hear the same sort of language that Time Inc. has been using to describe their vision of the future. Plus, there's that AOL connection with Ripp. Quarterly earnings report soon.
http://www.wsj.com/articles/inside-verizons-gamble-on-digital-media-1470099397

(If I've read the numbers correctly) Print sales are steady at 3 million/copy, with minimal drop-off since 2010. The great majority of sales are through subscription, though what (to me) is most interesting is the verified subscription of >120,000. Because of this, Time is able to claim in its Media Kit that total readership exceeds 11 million. Add to this the magazine's status as a legacy brand, its up-market demographic and the limited success of its online presence in a cluttered marketplace, and I think the print edition is safe for this year at least.

Update for passage of time and info/insight provided by @Anneinak

As Newsweek resumed publication in 2014 and is reportedly profitable it appears that currently it is possible to make money from a print newspaper. It appears that Time, unlike The Independent in the UK that recently stopped publishing a print edition, still has a sizable print circulation and it mainly sells via subscriptions (rather than via news stands which gives a more certain cash flow). The long term outlook is not very certain but the US print edition should last another 7 months. As I assume many subscriptions are annual and that many are bought toward the end of the year (as Xmas presents or renewals of past Xmas presents, I would guess that to stop the print edition without annoying people who have just bought a subscription Time would want to announce any plans well in advance. Newsweek indicated it would be going all digital on 25 July 2012, on 18 October 2012 it announced that the US print edition would cease on 31 Dec 2012. So if Time were going to follow the same pattern they would be making the first announcement in the next 12 weeks. 
As Time group publishes lots of other print magazines they would be sensible to ensure that stopping a print version of Time did not put customers off buying print subscriptions to their other magazines.

I'm increasing my probability estimate of this somewhat. Newsweek already eliminated its print edition. Time-Warner spun-off TIME magazine a couple of years ago as I understand it. It seems that, like newspapers, print magazines are facing severe revenue challenges due to the rise of digital journalism. As the revenue decreases, scope and quality of the publications probably also decreases -- a vicious circle. And, many people just don't seem to want to read the news via hard-copy platforms.

A: Time magazine is an extremely popular source of news, and has been around for a long time. It is widely supported and has actually been growing in popularity since 2013.

It is very hard for TIME to break a digital world that is saturated with magazine and newspaper companies trying to do the same thing. . They have been very successful with paper editions; it's very unlikely that they will translate completely into the digital world and abandon the paper world completely. Paper subscriptions have been going up since the beginning of the year, it would be a risky move to upset this profitable trend.

Time Magazine is far more popular than other magazines that stopped printing have been. Sales have actually increased since 2013, making an end to their print edition extremely unlikely. They are actually facing less competition these days than they have before due to lower circulation of other magazines.

My prediction: 15%
TIME magazine is a classic source of media and has been for years and years, and even though many magazines and other publications have switched over to online print, people will still continue to buy TIME magazines or years to come. Also, TIME has not hinted at all that they would be switching to online only.

Time is 93 years old and a lot of people like to read it the old fashioned way.  It was the most popular magazine in America as of 2013.  I feel as if TIME magazine has this historic place in society and that they would change.  The reason I am lowering the chances that TIME will go completely online by 2017 is that the other magazines that have had to go only online were much smaller and less relevant in American society compared to TIME.  For these reasons I am giving it a small chance that TIME goes solely to online before January 1, 2017.

Why this year and not last year? Or next year? There are good speculative answers to these questions, but they need to be asked. I saw some high probabilities from top forecasters, but it seems like the market is on the side of "Time still sells a lot of magazines every week and can continue to do so for a while". I'd give a 5% chance that they vanish from paper this year, and another ~20% that they switch to monthly or some other format. You can still sell a monthly periodical to doctors with waiting rooms, after all.

EXPERIMENT
Rather than hijack another thread, I thought I'd restart an experiment here where it might be more appropriate. The purpose of this experiment is to test some of the preconceptions we might hold as to the so-called "internet strategy" of TIME.

I think that TIME will recognize the end of the line for weekly print magazines, and will decide to throw in with technology. Every weekly print magazine will go the way of the dinosaur before 2020, and TIME will see the handwriting on the computer screen before then.

The trend is away from print, but as more periodicals abandon print, perhaps the few survivors will grow stronger.
Many other magazines have gone away or turned digital. Paper and ink are becoming scarcer and more expensive. Newsrooms have gotten smaller. Inevitable. Only real forecast is when.

For more anecdotal evidence, I've been paying attention to advertising as it might appear on any webpage associated with either Time Inc. or TIME magazine. My impressions are only based on a dozen or so such visits since the inception of this Question. My observations were limited by the fact that I employ a number of various script and ad-blockers with my browser. First, perhaps because of my blockers, I am not seeing any advertising at all for the bulk of my visits. As a recommendation to TIME, they should deliver some classy, non-obtrusive, minimal, single advertisement to every visitor by default (if blockers prevent generation of a custom ad). Second, for those ads that are delivered (I don't know why sometimes and sometimes not), the advertisers are of the type I identified previously in my anecdotal survey of a printed issue (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/90552 ); namely, very large corporations with massive advertising budgets placing "image" (versus product) placements. These advertisements were not just pick-ups of those in the printed issue. So, I'm thinking, and the whole point of this post, is that Time Inc. (or TIME) may be making big progress in improving its online advertising revenue. One could imagine that if a sufficient set of these very large (big ad budget) corporations (e.g., IBM) could be corralled with some type of multi-year special relationship (and price) "bundle" arrangement, Time Inc. might very well find the funds necessary to "cut-the-cord" (a bit at least) on the print side. This is all a long way of saying they may have gotten some topline breathing room, but rather than coast on it, they move with it. (+3)
Down 20% to be closer to consensus. Still think it likely (at some point) that the "weekly" will evolve into something else, possibly ~twice monthly.
Slimmed down and more frequent current issues will help them remain on print for now.
Its going to happen eventually, as their readership dies off, but not quite yet.

So I looked at an issue of TIME.
1) FYI, it is already less than a weekly edition (that is, it is already *not* published 52 times per year). There are some number of "combined issues." The number of combined issues appears to be at the publisher's discretion; so Time Inc. may already have plans to add another combined issue or two this year as compared to last. They could achieve some cost savings by reduced paper (and printing) and mailing costs (neither of which would likely exceed those of two stand-alone issues). So, we are not forecasting the "thing," but only the "name." (-5)
2) The quality of the paper is dramatically inferior to years past. Whatever tactile appeal magazines may have once had, is lost in TIME. Photo quality suffers as well.
3) The collection of advertisers is kind of funny. It's a slice of corporate America (mostly) that you need to see for yourself to get the feel. Big pharma (many), insurance companies (many), AARP and other senior citizen groups, banks, Volkswagen (curious), US Ad Council, and Mexican vacations. Plus an Amazon and another ad that likely reflects some traded advertising as part of their recent strategic relationships. In general, I saw the advertisers as representing very large firms with massive advertising budgets that are probably not required to justify their advertising spend in terms of effectiveness. It's image (versus product) advertising dollars that are farmed through agencies and the like. It would be just that collection of advertisers if there was some group that wanted to support a mainstream narrative of reality. These are not the kind of advertisers that will likely go away if there is a (further) frequency change; but perhaps more importantly, they are so locked in that they can be milked with the current frequency and rate hikes quite a bit longer.

Staying put, read up more on RIpp, and he does not strike me as the sentimental type: http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20151101/MEDIA_ENTERTAINMENT/311019991/joe-ripp-wants-everyone-to-believe-time-inc-is-a-media-company-for-the-21st-century-not-everyone-is-buying-it: 
of note: 'I never look back; I only look forward,' and` "What I said from the very first day I got here is that we are not a magazine company," he said. "By defining yourself by your distribution vehicle you limit your options: We defined ourselves as a paper distribution company while our audiences were moving to digital."`and my personal favourite ""Cutting costs is like peeling an onion," Ripp said. "Every layer you go down, you seem like you can't get to the next layer because there's too much crying along the way. But when you get there, you can make it.""
Then Ripp has a clear business head, http://www.wsj.com/articles/time-inc-shuts-down-all-you-first-print-magazine-closure-under-ceo-joe-ripp-1445276923.  Clearly not the same as TIME, but key to me was "at around 1.5 million for the past several years, newsstands sales had slid from around 400,000 in June 2012 to 280,000 in June of this year, according to the Alliance for Audited Media. But the real death knell, according to a person familiar with the matter, was a steep declined in ad sales."  Then looking at the print adverts recorded as 20% down, plus his vision, plus the hiring of Wong, I am going with @redacted they are working to a plan.  
Whether the plan unfolds in our time frame is a matter of advert revenue it seems, and getting shareholders to believe in the digital future.  Given timeframe, staying put, assuming constant down trend in advert revenues and shareholder dissatisfaction, and Ripp says Wong is to "accelerate" his plan.

Time Magazine is circulated to over 3m doctors offices and waiting rooms in the US. This volume cannot easily be replaced by electronic means even if other subscriptions may continue to be cancelled by individual subscribers. 3m+ circulation is easily sufficient to make it economically viable and profitable to continue with physical circulation of the magazine. Moreover, recent ciruclation figures have been relatively stable for the past few years, suggesting that the impact of online distribution has already occurred and further erosion will be slow - possibly linked to the mortality rates of the older generation of subscribers. Moreover, Nancy Gibb - the current chief editor - was quoted in saying in 2013 that the magazine "will always exist in print".  Finally, magazine publication is the core business of Time Inc and Time Magazine is the flagship product:  A decision not to publish in print would be a radical departure in business strategy that is unlikely to occur first in its flagship prouct - we will likely see moves in this direction first in other publications, including Sports Illustrated etc.  I might increase my probability of this event if those type of moves occur first, but for the moment the probability has to be very low (although with the caveat here that the YES is predicated on an "announcement" of the move rather than implementation of such a move, so in theory they could announce that they will stop printing in 2025 or so.
